title: Iran warns will defend itself after Israeli strikes on military sites
summary: Tehran confirmed Israel had targeted military sites around the capital and in other provinces, saying the raids caused 'limited damage' but killed four soldiers. Iran insisted it had the 'right and the duty' to defend itself.

title: Georgia pro-Western opposition parties reject 'falsified' election results
summary: The opposition disputed the results of its election after officials said the ruling party led the crucial vote which could decide whether the country pivots to embrace the West or falls back into Russia's orbit. Many Georgians viewed the election as a make-or-break referendum on the opportunity to join the European Union.

title: In Gaza, survivors flee from Jabalia refugee camp
summary: The inhabitants of the largest camp in the Gaza Strip, suffering from starvation and bombings by the Israeli army, are gradually leaving.

title: 2024 US elections: How Viktor Orban is shaping Donald Trump's campaign
summary: Hungary's nationalist prime minister has spent tens of millions of euros to successfully influence the Republican candidate's campaign.

title: Dominique Méda: 'A small, affordable and sustainable electric car can be made in France, a choice that would enable a just transition'
summary: The crisis facing European car manufacturers has more to do with their inability to produce a car that meets consumer needs than with the standards imposed by the EU, observed the philosopher and sociologist in her column.

title: Tom Wesselmann: The biting, erotic irony of a unique body of work
summary: The Fondation Louis Vuitton in Paris is holding a retrospective of this American artist and precursor of pop art, whose paintings and installations rework the classic codes of the nude to critique consumer society.

title: Harris or Trump? The Washington Post and LA Times, under the influence of their owners, withdraw endorsements
summary: Jeff Bezos, head of Amazon and owner of The Washington Post, is suspected of imposing this decision in anticipation of another possible Trump presidency, a few days after a similar choice by the owner of the Los Angeles Times.

title: EU-Mercosur agreement: Negotiations speed up to France's dismay
summary: Within the European Union, France is increasingly isolated in its fight against this free-trade agreement.

title: Cyclist's death in Paris sparks public debate on road violence
summary: In addition to 'sharing the road' between the growing number of cyclists, pedestrians and motorists, elected officials and urban planners have been exploring ways to reduce road fatalities.

title: Is the 'America first' mission accomplished?
summary: Over the past four years, the Biden administration has cemented Trump's shift toward protectionism, focusing on relocating strategic industries amid Chinese competition and working-class discontent. The results are mixed.

title: Almost 50 years apart, two French trials symbolize the long conceptual battle on rape
summary: The trial of dozens of men accused of raping Gisèle Pelicot while she was drugged has shed light on the significance and relevance of ideas generated over the last 50 years by feminist thinkers and gender studies in France.

title: Georgia votes in 'existential' election for the country's future
summary: Voters are being asked to choose between a government that wants to draw closer to Moscow and an opposition that is much more pro-European.

title: Russian strikes on Ukraine kill seven in Dnipro and Kyiv
summary: The strikes on Friday evening came less than 48 hours after Russia finished hosting the BRICS summit in Kazan, where Putin faced calls from world leaders to end the conflict.

title: Moody's cuts France outlook, opening door to credit downgrade
summary: France's new finance minister Antoine Armand noted the decision Friday but maintained that the country is able to carry out 'far-reaching reforms,' adding that France has economic strength and vowed to restore its finances

title: Influencers send young people to Australian mines
summary: Mining influencers – young backpackers and Australian videographers on YouTube and TikTok – are encouraging Internauts to join them at Australian mines to make money. Their content is proving good business for the industry.

title: In Brazil, fires and the destruction of nature inspire artists
summary: Galleries and museums are displaying works that depict climate change and its brutality for ecosystems. For the artists, they are a way of sounding the alarm.

title: Israel targets the few remaining journalists in northern Gaza
summary: The Israeli army has accused six Palestinian reporters from Al-Jazeera, who are covering the intense violence of the current offensive in the region, of being Hamas and Islamic Jihad fighters.

title: In the country of Georgia, the government campaigns 'for peace'
summary: In the run-up to the October 26 parliamentary elections, the Georgian Dream party is using the war in Ukraine as a deterrent.

title: Watchmakers in Switzerland cut back on working hours
summary: Falling sales of luxury watches, particularly in China, are forcing Swiss watchmakers to reduce working hours in their workshops.

title: Caroline Fourest: 'Let's avoid abusing #MeToo to settle scores and get rid of people'
summary: In an interview with Le Monde, the French essayist acknowledges that there is a continuum between sexist offenses and sexual violence, but believes that we need to distinguish between them, in order to respond in a graduated and proportionate way.

title: Stanislav Asseyev, Ukrainian journalist: 'We have a huge army of deserters roaming the country'
summary: The writer, a former soldier and ex-prisoner of the Russians, underlines the despair gripping Ukrainian fighters and warns of the difficulty of mobilizing new troops against Russia.

title: 2024 US presidential election: Try our swing state results simulator
summary: Seven swing states will tip the US presidential election's outcome in favor of either Kamala Harris or Donald Trump. The other states, meanwhile, are already so polarized that they can no longer switch sides.

title: Japan votes in tight election, with new PM Ishiba on shaky ground
summary: New Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba and his Liberal Democratic Party, which has governed Japan for almost all of the past seven decades, are facing potentially their worst result since 2009.

title: Bulgaria votes in seventh election after three years of deadlock
summary: Six consecutive votes have so far failed to yield a stable government, as the political turmoil has favored the country's far right.

title: Georgia elections: Pro-Russian Georgian Dream holds onto power
summary: The electoral commission announced on Sunday morning that Georgian Dream had won with 54% of the vote, despite protests from opposition parties. This will enable billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili to form a government, but risks dashing the country's hopes of joining the European Union.

title: Lithuania votes in runoff election amid security concerns about Russia
summary: The vote is likely to replace the ruling conservatives with a center-left coalition, while leaving intact the NATO and EU member's strong support for Ukraine.

title: Taiwan says China held 'combat' patrol around island after latest US arms sales
summary: China deployed fighter jets and drones around Taiwan on Sunday, Taipei said, after Beijing slammed the latest round of US arms sales to the island.

title: Uruguay is gripped by cocaine trafficking amid elections
summary: As the gateway to Europe for the new cocaine routes, Montevideo, once known for its tranquillity, is now gripped by drug-related crime. This issue is at the heart of the campaign in Sunday's general elections.

title: Lina Khan, the woman making Big Tech tremble
summary: The president of the Federal Trade Commission, America's antitrust agency, is fighting the big monopolies. She irritates Republicans and is participating in the Biden administration's efforts to defend its actions against inflation.

title: In Venezuela, Nicolas Maduro drops new officials and tightens up his team
summary: Three months after Maduro's disputed re-election, a former oil minister was arrested, while the European Union awarded the Sakharov Prize to opponents Maria Corina Machado and Edmundo Gonzalez Urrutia.

title: Puff Daddy in Le Monde: From bling-bling media personality to inmate 37 452-054
summary: American businessman Sean Combs, accused of multiple rapes, is the target of a federal investigation into potential sex trafficking. It was already against a backdrop of violence that the rapper and producer first appeared in Le Monde, on January 1, 1997.

title: How Emmanuel Macron can be tracked: Watch the first episode of StravaLeaks
summary: 'StravaLeaks' (1/3). Three of the world's most important leaders have been put in danger due to their security guards' use of a sports social media app, Strava. The first part of our investigation looks into how the French president can be tracked thanks to his bodyguards' love of running.

title: Strava, the exercise app filled with security holes
summary: In recent years, journalists and curious observers have discovered that individuals tasked with sensitive operations, particularly soldiers, have shared their physical activity on Strava, endangering their mission, their identity and even their safety.
